comments.text: I have a RTX 2060. I have had random black screens, and a recent blue screen with the current Driver 576.52. I had to roll back to version 566.36 and that driver is for Dec 5, 2024. I have used Nvidia for 20 years, and I have never had any issues until 2025. Every driver after 566.36 there has been issues. from no signals, to Sync issues, black screen, and blue screen. I don't know what changed at Nvidia, but I don't plan to update until all issues have been fixed. There is a rumor going around on their forms about Nvidia using an AI program that updates their drivers instead of a human. If that's true, that is the dumbest decision they have ever made. Humans test for errors, and AI doesn't. I would bet money that the AI is there so they don't have to pay a human to run test, or builds. If anyone has any issues with there cards 566.36 was the last working driver a cross the board for all cards.
comments.author: @Drew19822002

comments.text: The RTX 5070 upgrade from a 3060 has been THE WORST PC UPGRADE since Windows ME. Every driver since launch has been 3 steps forward 2 steps back. On 3 separate occasions, with 3 different WHQL Studio drivers, has resulted in OBS Encoder Crash during live streaming. The WHQL Game driver also resulted in the same Encoder Crash. OBS does not crash but the encoder fails as the driver crashed and restarted causing live stream to abruptly end. Only restarting OBS is the only option to try and get a stream live again. Davinci Resolve render times vary vastly with different drivers. On numerous occasions the 3060 can render faster than or equal to an $800 AIB Partner OC 5070. With the DR 20 Beta 3 and now the Beta 4, I can finally see 5070 outperform the 3060. Very disappointing results and I'm sure NVIDA does not care as they already have the money in hand.

comments.text:
PC Gamer used to be an amazing magazine in the 90's, especially the UK side. They were very hard on publishers, developers, manufacturers and always had the consumer in mind. They were not afraid to turn down adverts or to have a big two page advert of a game only for the page later to completely tear it apart with a 30% score. I was a HUGE fan of the magazine for this very reason - they used the entire score scale and not just the top 30% and this let me trust their opinion.

Then around 2005 things went downhill - the new writers were very biased and huge Blizzard & Valve fanboys and the magazine lost its hard edge mentality. They had to compete with free online sites so they bent over backwards to please publishers and look what PC Gamer has turned into today ...

comments.text: in the USDM it makes sense 300$ competitive for 2nd hand market range cards that perform around this card....i already knew VRAM is more an issue with total ram buffer/bandwidth than "envelope". 4060ti 16gb v 8gb....vs 256bit 3070....perform similar just bc of the L cache/changes to ADA lovelace over ampere. They cheaped out on the vram bitrate/ceiling and sold a card on par with a 3070 claiming 16gb of "performance" BUT THEN offer 128bit paired with it since it had bolstered L cache from the newer gen node. All to cash in on this vram hysteria among un-informed buyers....now we got benchmarks with cs2/cod/starfield etc....."showcasing" the difference in 8gb vs 16gb with the 4060ti and the 5060, 5060ti 8gb-16gb....which completel7y validates these things on 1440p. Globally i cant speak on this cards price/value etc propositions. But in the US for 300$ youd have to find a cheaper 3070 or 4060ti or a bargain of a deal on a 3060ti and once those are sniped up by the end of the year/holiday sales/system upgrade season...i can see these 8 pin 5060 cards selling for sure once the 2nd hand market grows scarce. Im sure these prices/globally also fit this trend of pushing most buyers/entry to budget range buyers into the used market or to buy rdna3/amd cards still on shelves/liquidated. Before all that exists as options are a 5060/intel option or rdna4...by q4 for if theyre intent on getting a new gpu/upgrade etc. Either way considering how aggressively priced these are in the US at 300$ it has me wondering how much some 5060 laptop/packages will be offered at each concurrent price/point. Something with decent ram/speeds/timings and a decent cooling system for some high/ideal clocks on cores carrying gaming loads with a gpu like the 5060 could be a nice system to access/utilize before the 2nm samsung nodes start getting utilzed in gpu's in the future. Either that or wait a year for the not even released yet portables to come out....then consider a 300$ gpu like this for an egpu dock....until you can find a 2nm samsung node/gpu of the future for an actual/beast build. Id consider those 2 things vs full out buying into a platform currently. By the time 2nm samsung nodes are in our hands....were looking at a gaming landscape where gta 6 will be on PC and forza horizon 6 and witcher 4 are also widely in rotation of many gamers libraries/wish lists. Id consider the last gen amd x3d cpu for am5 set to launch to close out that platform/socket, or a future socket/chipset and to actually be SERIOUS about considering a decent build THEN vs now. In reality if amd were still selling a 5800x3d or 5700x3d for a decent enough price it wouldnt be a bad "multiplayer" title build with a 300$ gpu like the 5060. Which will clearly be largely reliant on DLSS4 or FG for AAA/SINGLE player titles but most definitely enough for anything on lower/competitive oriented settings. Basically the lowest barrier to entry to accomplish both for a gamer on a budget. Only thing VRAM could even make sense to me with when it comes to entry/mid range cards would be something like DLDSR for older/gen titles where these cards could still keep on.

comments.text:
Frankly, I think most of you people are being too mean (edit: about the 5060 performance, not about Nvidia's worrying dishonesty).
Yes, Nvidia sucks, yes, enthusiastic reviews can't be trusted. And no, you shouldn't run to buy this.
...but you should never buy freshly released cards. This will make bad prices, bad marketing and bad reviews fade away.

Eventually, thanks to non-gaming uses of GPUs, all new card seem to naturally flow into their spot that guarantees a very, very similar performance/price ratio from $200 to $2500.
Basically there's almost no point of diminishing returns and the market self-regulates pretty well because of higher and more technical demand.

The 5070 was absolutely crazy with the prices we've seen the first weeks. After AMD rivals came out, it shifted towards more reasonable prices. Nothing great, just where it belongs.

Nvidia has to try marketing tricks ( *cough* - *lies* - *cough* ) and reviewers sometimes have to try to excite viewer's interest ( *cough* - *bait* - *cough* ). But the truth is we'll never have a new incredible generation of game-changing cards like the 10 series. Because.

comments.text:
The problem for me, apart from nVIdia sh*tty practices, is people are still treating nvidia GPU's as just a gaming accessory, when these days they do so much more than just play vidya games. Yet no reviews ever feature 'AI' performance benchmarks for the 50 series, as in how long it takes LLM's to do tasks locally via your own hardware.
This is why I bought an overpriced 5080, because I am not just gaming with my GPU anymore. I'm using a lot of AI tools that perform much better with a 50 series GPU installed. Yet people still treat these things like all they are used for is games.
Where's the benchmarks showing a 5090 generating a 2-minute video in FramePack, or an image in Stable Diffusion, or how quickly a 'chatgpt' like bots model will respond etc?
If you just benchmark games and nothing else, you're leaving out a major part of the card's function.

And more and more consumer software is adding GPU powered AI tools, like Paintshop Pro and Vegas Pro etc. 

Sure, nvidia needs to do better, but also reviewers need to stop treating all GPU's as nothing but gaming devices. We no longer need reviewers just asking 'Can it run Crysis?' as they have always done, we now need reviewers to also ask "Can it run an LLM"
I think both sides of this argument, nvidia, the reviewers and the consumer, need to get with the times and realise video cards aren't what they used to be.

Cannot recall seeing anyone benchmarking and doing a video comparing any 50 series GPU to an Intel Arc or AMD card when it comes to 'AI' tasks, it's always 'herp a derp, here's how they run playing Doom Dark Ages'.

GPU use has shifted, people need to start realising that.
comments.author: @TheCunningStunt

comments.text:

comments.text:
Graphics engineer here. 

Funny how these same guys were saying that ray tracing is a gimmick and Nvidia is a fraud for pushing it. Then DLSS was a fraud because it was "fake" pixels. Now DLSS is good, and ray tracing is good, but path tracing is fraud and frame gen is fraud.

You're not buying is piece of metal. You're buying a product, and it's a combination of software and hardware. Should Nvidia be more open - yeah, by all means, but cry me a river man, you're so bitter about it.

And reviews? You are so non-essential, you think you're providing some kind of a vital service. If I buy a GPU and it's good - fine, if I buy it and it's bad - I'll shop elsewhere next time. Not once have I used your review as the main basis for my purchasing decisions, if anything - you're the "baby's first impressions", and you're entirely interchangeable with about a dozen other reviewers just here on YouTube. I don't care about your livelihood if it involves the company that sells me stuff having to cater to you. That's cost, and you don't eat that - I do.

And about 3080? You were begrudgingly saying it's "OK", because it was too expensive. And now your memory has gone out the windows "it was a good product!". Because the history has shown it to be such. 

I would say that you are leaches, but you're barely above that in my eyes, so not a high bar. Get off your high horse and take a good look in the mirror, Mr glorified carpet seller.

comments.text:
Firstly it has nothing to do with the size of the media outlet.

Secondly our ad-spots are just that, ad-spots embedded within the videos. There are no strings attached here, we provide the ad-spot and the advertiser pays for it, that's where the deal begins and ends.

It is in no way the same thing, there are no strings attached with the ad-spots. Advertisers don't get to dictate the content in any capacity, they can't even pick the content their ad is shown in, they have no control over anything.

So comparing what Nvidia is doing here to our ad-spots is truly bizarre as they are in no way comparable.

comments.text: I'm an Nvidia user, but more so because of 4K performance, not because I have a deep love for the company. To me, as an enthusiast user, I took a look at the actual numbers and had to decide where to reliably go from there. I do this every time I upgrade. My CPUs is from AMD and has been for the last eight years. So I'm not really concerned about who manufactures the components. But I know that at the end of the day, this market isn't about the enthusiast user. It's about the normie who wants to buy a PC, and does only have a minimal understanding of its components. This is the market segment which Nvidia is really after. For this, they have to bring their size to bear and win with buzzwords that sound really magical. Neither AMD nor Intel, who are competitive in that segment, can't really afford that, nor do they have the same atmospheric clout that Nvidia always has. To me, it sounds like some form of false advertisement scheme. It is even worse when influencers and reviewers become complicit in this scheme. They might gain VIP cards from Nvidia, but hopefully, the middle finger from the community.

comments.text:
The whole "MFG = performance" is so sacrilegious because "performance" is the actual, physical feedback you, as the player, get from your inputs. And higher performance = higher framerates = higher rate of feedback of your actions. The great "sin" of graphics was trying to sacrifice the performance for visual fidelity.
What Jensen Huang is trying to do is sell you just another visual fidelity feature as a "performance increase", despite the fact that MFG does nothing to increase the rate of feedback of your actions (as the generated frames are not based on your input, but on the input of the previous frames). So Jensen Huang isn't just trying to sell you a "sin", he's trying to sell it as a virtue.
And then when reviewers rightfully reject his narrative, he starts putting down pressure. It's incredibly scummy and dishonest.

I haven't bought an nVidia card in over a decade. Put your money where it matters. Consumers do have power, they just need to have the guts to go with AMD or Intel. Money is king to nVidia. I don't use frame generation, it is blurry, causes weird pixel artifacts, odd glows, just doesn't look good and makes games feel laggy. 
I don't use ray tracing. The performance hit for fancy puddles and funky shadows just doesn't justify the performance hit when enabled. Well, that's my opinion but each to their own.

Manipulating reviewers is just unethical. It won't help nVidia long term so why bother. In a few days those questionable reviews will be exposed and anyone that buys a card based on those reviews will probably feel pretty badly ripped off. If nVidia just did nothing, that would probably be better for them than being exposed.

comments.text:
There's another distributing disturbing aspect to these manipulation tactics that you would surely have got to with more time.  Many people are now using AI chatbots instead of traditional search engines to get their info.  The bot replies that the 5060 is 300 percent faster than the 3070 or whatever is stated in the previews since that's all that's out there.  One may never see the original sources, and therefore not in a position to assess credibility. 

It is ironic that the chatbot is likely relying on Nvidia hardware in generating such output.  I'm not actually saying that it's somehow tuned to make favourable statements about Nvidia products.  Make of that what you will.  As these LLMs percolate down to the typical non-technical individual on the street who might just take the output at face value, the danger of creating "alternative truths" becomes ever greater.  We've already seen this with the Internet and social media, but that may pale in comparison to what is to come.

comments.text:
** I have not watched any 5060 preview content as I'm not interested in it, I'm just talking about what is shown in this video and previous preview content I've watched! **
It isn't really misleading if those previews disclose the preview guidelines though?
You would have a point if those previews made no mention of the preview guidelines, but they generally seem to. You even show it them disclosing guidelines in the reviews at the same time as making it sound like it's all hush hush.
Later in the video "it's really about you guys getting accurate information" implies that the information given in the previews is not accurate, but I don't remember you bringing up any information that isn't accurate?
But I do think it depends on the focus of a channel, disclosure of guidelines, and how the content is represented.
But generally if it is done well I think channels should do 'preview' content whenever they want (e.g. I've never had any issues with DF's preview content, but it's pretty much the only preview content that I've ever watched).

If people read/watch that content, don't actually read/listen to what is presented and only look at the graphs, with ZERO thought about whether those graphs represent how they will use the product then RIP bozo you deserve it, it is the buyers fault and not the previewers (again, as long as the usual info/disclosures are there!). 
It is unfortunate that this can negatively affect discoverability of proper review content.

Of course, trying to influence actual reviews is a whole different thing and even if I sometimes disagree with some of your opinions I watch the channel because I trust the integrity of your data.

comments.text:
The industry is so cutthroat now, to the point where just coming out with good products might not be enough as the competitor could use underhanded marketing tactics to bury your product. So the companies all try to do the same thing - make good product and lean heavy on marketing. The problem is that making good product is much harder, compared to marketing where they can pretty much just throw money at it. So companies, when pressed, will usually just come out with so-so product and try to use the marketing machinery to get it past.

Thing is, if using marketing to get a bad product sold doesn't work on consumers, companies won't do it (or those that refuse to not do it will eventually go out of business). But somehow it still works. So, pie on our faces, then. Any way you look at it, it's really up to us consumers to curtail this.

comments.text:
I'm not happy with Nvidia :) there i said it. Last week Hardware unboxed you asked (sort of) why the 9070 xt is so expensive. It is because this shit (wich kinda is worse then amd, although they are not clean), is only there with Nvidia. While i already wanted an amd card for various other reason (more raster focus). Like even with equal frame per dollar, i would buy 9070, also the drivers dont help either, plus removal of physx. Also the 4070 ti (super) were massively expensive (900€base price spiking to 1150€ for Asus tuf like models). Somehow this was not teh case yet in USA, and australia but now it seems to be. They compensated with slightly lower msrp now, but same thing remains true.

Also amd card respond to market situation, 7900 xt doenst sell well, it slowly goes down (within the minimum margins of course), 4070 ti super NEVER moved down not a single dime, then after 8 months it moved up because stopped production, then still another 6-8 months no blackwell.

So i kinda know Amd card will get cheaper over time, unless demand crazes true two years. I'm all patient.

The 'fake' ray tracing and higher price of 2000 rtx series started my dislike for NVidia, then the crazy, 3000 prices, (while amd 6000 were crazy they eventually got down to crazy deal prices, even the 7000 series barely reach now). 4000 series (without USA/australia discount see earlier), was really bad, i didn't get the positive reviews/mentality about it. Glad the 5000 series kinda finally gets that negative mentality to reality. So i hate Nvidia, i hate their review protocols, i hate their fake frame, i hate their (for me) almost fake ray tracing (but especially uses to much power to be a worthwhile feature).

And for those who will tell me my 5070 Ti can't do PhysX, I had a GTX 1050 Ti laying around so I also put it in my system, and for now this 1050 Ti runs all the hardware-accelerated tasks like Discord, part of Chromium browsers and video decoding on Youtube. comments.author: @duurc

comments.text: @duurc  You can see plenty of fps. More and more fps isn't equally as much of an improvement though. Diminishing returns. You could render 4k 60 fps natively but you'd be using all the processing power on doing that, the game rendering 4k DLSS Performance 60 fps will look ten times more graphically impressive. Resolution and fps are not free, they come at the cost of processing power that then wouldn't be going towards what is important: the actual graphics on screen.

comments.text:
I wonder if Nvidia is doing all of this with the 5000 series cards recently, to push the gaming market away from their product lineup. I mean, it's certainly up their alley. They have a long history of doing something shady/shenanigans style something or the other during some release or the other to push some intended result on their end. It's kind of a 'if you know, you know' situation with them, because you have to have a better understanding of their entire mindset as a corporate entity. It's in their name. Nvidia = Invida, Latin Roman for Envy = Greek personification of Nemisis. They know they can get away with most if not all of their tricks, because they know you will still want the product of their trade. For some reason or another. For a while that was gaming. 

But now Nvidia has learned that there are new markets to explore that can potentially pay much more money. Gaming is now just a old flag they keep bearing on the ship of their corporate entity. One they are potentially looking to be able to remove. 

Why not just drop gaming then if that's the end goal? They can't just do that. Not without a 'good' reason to do so. Good being relative to the entire mode of operation around being a corporate entity of envy. Again, it's in their name. 

If the gaming crowd still wants Nvidia gpu's by and large because the others aren't caught up or ahead of them enough yet to make the change on that side of things; then they still have reason to take the money of said gamers. They're still the best, somehow. Hence why they always try to move that goalpost somehow. Enter in the new features that no other gpu has, etc so forth; making the other companies have to follow their lead on that in trying to catch up that way instead. 

But. 

AMD at least, and perhaps Intel someday if they keep at it, are looking like they could potentially catch up at least in AMD's case mostly. 

Not just in raw performance metrics if they actually get their act together on that finally, but also in those software addons and gimmicks that Nvidia does then drops later while moving the goal post again. Nvidia thought raytracing was going to be their holy grail, along with some other niceties. But things have changed in that regards. Even Intel has traded blows with that. 

So Nvidia in my mind, is trying to use methods of reducing the fanbase in terms of gaming. This will give them financial justification it isn't 'worth it' to keep supplying the gaming crowd except maybe possibly on the highest end card releases only. (Again, gotta be the best, for sake of envy.)

We'll see in about 5 to 7 years if I am correct on this I think, as it will probably be a slow roll down of things at first, prior to sudden news that only something like 90 series or titan cards will be sold; with the rest of their money now made via all their other hardware, software, etc.

comments.text:
The elephant in the room that nobody is talking about is the 4 nanometer wall. Nvidia has been on TSMC's 4 nanometer process since the 4000 series. The days of stacking transistors on silicon to gain power are over. You can't stack transistors past 4 nanometer in proximity to each other without the electrons jumping and shorting out the the circuit. That's why Nvidia went all in on AI up scaling. They shortened up the VRAM for room to slap a few more transistors onto the board to show some raw computing upgrade.  This is what all future generations of video cards and CPU's by EVERY tech company will look like. Until motherboard manufacturers start coming up with solutions to run multiple CPU's or GPU's, or dedicated AI processors, expect the 6000 series to be more frame gen specs.

It's bad that Nvida is buying reviews. It's bad that people in the tech review space are playing along. But it's also bad that all of the "uncorrupted" reviewers in the tech space completely turn a blind eye to the 4 nanometer wall and just cry: "Wah, NVIDIA BAD! THEY GIVE US LESS!" All of these reviwers know why these cards are not technically impressive. Nobody is talking about it. That's just as disingenuous as people fluffing Nvidia for early access. You don't make yourself look good by calling other people out, while you your self are farming rage bait about the current generation of cards, and not discussing why these cards are not technically impressive.

@28:28 "Gamers need to let Nvidia know they're not happy about this."

Guys, gamers are letting Nvidia know they're not happy about this. That's why the 5070 Ti and 5070 are less over MSRP than what the 9070 XT is.  Demand for those Nvidia products is down, and that's why the price for those products has gone down. But in the last week you put out not one, but two videos talking about how the 9070 XT is so over MSRP compared to the 5070 Ti and 5070 that gamers should get the 5070 Ti and 5070 instead.  I'm not saying your conclusions in those videos were wrong, but to advise gamers to buy Nvidia products and then advise gamers to punish Nvidia for their behavior later in the same week is inconsistent at best, and hypocritical at worst.

And while I'm here... the title for your "The Radeon RX 9070 XT is Not $600" video should have been "Has Nvidia Thrown Away Their Mindshare?", because I think that's what's really going on.  Nvidia's history of anti-consumer practices, combined with the poor uplift in performance of the 50-series and the good performance of RDNA4, is finally causing gamers to abandon Nvidia.

comments.text:
I've got a 5070 and it's a perfectly fine card, but that's kind of the problem? I upgraded from a 2060 super, and I'd say, relative to the rest of their generation, the 2060S and 5070 are pretty comparable cards. The 2060S was a pricey card for its time, but you could buy it for $350 or even lower within a few months of launch. Now you're lucky to find a $550 5070 at msrp, and it's nothing impressive for the tier. 

12gb of vram is mediocre, and I've had some dx12 stability issues with compatible drivers. It's not much of an upgrade over a 4070 super, and 4x frame gen is a waste of time because it looks so blurry and filled with artifacts.

Not sure if I'll go AMD on my next gpu, or maybe even Intel if they put out a good card in a generation or two, but Nvidia is just too expensive for what you get.

comments.text:
So basically GPP v2.0, except targeting reviewers. Also out of sites picked, gaming sites, like PC Gamer and Game Radar are pretty much used to abuse like this. Gaming companies are notorious to not send early review copies to unfavorable outlets and blacklist them. So they are already used to doing "favorable" stuff on gaming side. They are basically extended marketing arm of big publishers under third party name. Hence why I stopped reading them. A lot of stuff they put out are just pieces being favorable to publishers. Which plays really well into what nVidia wants to do.

Also this date to release was super hand picked, they know everyone will be too busy and reviews will be late, except from favorable sources. It is such a terrible abuse of the system. Hence why I always say, not being in those early programs and being blacklisted in modern capitalism, is badge of honor, because only honest wear it. Blacklisting isn't there to stop unfair practices, it is there to cage too honest. And I wouldn't be shocked if someone actually took those sites, game publishers, or in this case nVidia, plus whole gaming journalism under microscope, there would be hell of a lot wrong found, if not illegal.

comments.text:
I was seeing tech media fallout with companies for some time now. You couldn't be trusted to give objective reviews of a hardware and would fill news with drama or forced examples to mislead the public. For example, Gamers Nexus video about how Nvidia is giving you less is logically flawed as it ties performance to a flagship die which always were wonky in size and pricing rather than 80s die. Then Hardware Unboxed did terrible review of RTX 5060 Ti where they used cherry picked examples of 4k gaming. A card meant for 1080p was taken into scenarios where it is not meant to be used. However, that logic of course doesn't really apply to anyone wanting to buy RTX 5060 Ti for 4k, does it? The moment you actually need to game at those resolutions, you discover that your brand new GPU barely gives you 30 FPS.

Tech media are becaming self serving clickbait matter. Electronics companies gave up on their brand image and increasingly disregards independent media coverage.  Gamers themselves are increasingly out of touch with reality and in full coping mode since they desires left them unable to afford the very hardware they claimed that they want. Sudden move towards 4k had increased computational costs 4 times and for that we needed an entirely new tier of hardware which gamers are now crying that they can't afford. Oh the irony!

I only had seen decline in recent years from every side. Nor anything will improve in a short term as we are in downward spiral at the moment.

comments.text:
It became scummy since they introduced raytracing, then upscaling, then frame generation. Long live the 10 series, even the previous gen Maxwell cards are hanging on. I'm on a laptop with a "750ti", and friends with 970, 1050 and 1050ti. All these current garbage won't make that change anytime soon...unless we can get Titan XP or 1080ti cards.

As for bad GPUs versus bad game optimization, it goes both ways. If game devs know that they are restrained by VRAM then they would have did their best to save it as much as possible. There is no reason why they cannot.

On the other hand - seeing how VRAM size for these lower end cards went backwards the past few generations while the flagship just kept getting bigger, I can't blame the developers being unable to hold their ground. And you have to remember that these developers actively work with the GPU manufacturer for guidance with using their hardware the best way. In the end, it should be blamed on the GPU manufacturer in the end. Or that's how I think about it.

comments.text: The 5070 should've been the 5060 Ti 16GB. No worthless 8GB, and the 5060 should've been the 12GB card (kind of like, idk, the freaking 3060 was?). Cause if we're being honest, it was the "xx60 Ti" class of cards that has (historically) been that sweet spot between the lower end "xx60" and upper midrange to "entry level" high end "xx70" classes. For those who couldn't (or simply didn't want/need to) buy the higher end, more enthusiast tier of cards, the "xx60 Ti"s have always had that feeling of just really getting some serious bang for your buck. While Turing didn't have a Ti model for the 2060, they still released the 2060 Super that was literally a down-binned 2080. Which gave it a bump in VRAM the way you'd expect for it to be able to handle slightly higher resolutions/texture settings. And when you look at the performance of said 2060 Super, it surpassed the previous gen "xx80" class card (1080) and was not even too far off from matching the legendary Pascal flagship 1080 Ti in rasterized performance. Then with Ampere, we had the 3060 Ti which was a massive success -- barring the fact that most of that generation has aged poorly due to suffering from inadequate VRAM capacities. However, when VRAM is not a limiting factor, the 3060 Ti could easily outperform nearly all of the entire Turing lineup (being just above the 2080 Super). These huge uplifts gen over gen were exactly what made the Ti or Super variants of "xx60" class cards so well received. The 3060 Ti (and 3070 / 3070 Ti naturally) had no business being restricted to a measly 8GB frame buffer. And the 3060 8GB (which was more in-line with the 2070) should have been the only 8GB card in the entire lineup, since it still would've technically been an upgrade over the previous 2060 6GB, 1660/1660 Super/1660 Ti 6GB, and 1060 6GB iterations. But...things changed for the worse with Lovelace. At a time now where 8GB had already been starting to show it's limitations (even at 1080p), the 4060 should have been the card to make 12GB "the bottom line". Since Nvidia has all but discontinued the "xx50" class of cards that was once the actual "entry level" starting point for gamers looking to slap together a PC where games are at least "playable". Those wouldn't feel like such bad value at 8GB, since the prior "xx50" cards often had the least amount of VRAM of the whole lineup as it is. But when you go back to the gen over gen improvement for "xx60" Ti or Super models, Lovelace was a complete joke. The 4060 Ti was not only limited to the same 8GB that made its otherwise "MVP" predecessor prematurely obsolete, but even after we got a 16GB variant the sheer rasterization performance just wasn't ever there. It was so close to the 3060 Ti that the two were often tied, or outperformed one another by a mere few %. Frame gen is the ONLY way the 4060 Ti could reflect any sort of meaningful jump in performance, yet that's precisely what's become the main problem now. The 5060 Ti has received essentially the exact same treatment as the 4060 Ti, and VRAM shortcomings aside it's the most egregious offense is even the 16GB model just BARELY manages to outperform the 3070 Ti 8GB (when VRAM doesn't hinder the latter). But it's still well below the 3080, and sits in the same performance class as its last 2 predecessors. We used to get previous gen-"xx80" class performance from the next gen's "xx60" Ti or Super variants. Now they can't even manage to offer that from an "xx80" card that's TWO generations behind them. Oh how far the mighty have fallen.

comments.text:
@berengerchristy6256  No it wasn't it had a very odd VRAM design. 3.5GB was fast, 512MB was slow. the card had intense shuttering above 3.5GB usage.
The 390 was the same price, its around the same performance has had double the VRAM. The 390 also had full dx12 support and Vulcan support the 970 does not and doesn't fully support async compute.
If you knew anything about computers back then it was no brainer which card. I know many are ignorant and just went Nvidia. Ultimately it was the 980ti that was a beast of a card and lived for a long time from that gen but 6GB of VRAM was still quite limiting as it aged.
the RX 580 8GB is an evolution of the r9 390 and card had a very good reputation for a long time because it had the features and the VRAM to do just that. 3.5GB of VRAM became obsolete even when it came out, GTA5 could have used 4GB of VRAM.

New computers in that market segment will come with 5080 GPUs (which still leverage the latest deCoders and NPUs btw) because drum roll OLDER CARDS ARE NO LONGER IN PRODUCTION.

What do you expect these computers to use as GPUs? Recycled used cards from old machines?

The fact remains that the vast majority of computers don't need more than 8GB VRAM, and this step on the product stack is for those computers.

People keep saying " why does nVidia make these cards?", well, that is why they make them, there is a market for them. It is for users who need a basic video card and don't want to pay extra for memory they will never use. Not everything is about high end gaming.

comments.text:
The 5060 is such a borrowing release.
1. Only 8 GB VRAM
2. It cannot be a fast card. The 4060 was about 12% faster than the 3060 12 GB and the 5060 Ti 8 GB is 33% faster. And the 5060 has to fit in between these two cards.
So the 5060 will be about ~20% faster than a 3060 12 GB in the cases where it does not run out of memory. So if you have a 3060 there is no reason to upgrade.


3. If your old 1060 breaks and you need a new card. Then the 5060 might be the card for you if you cannot stretch the budget for a 5060 Ti 16 GB version or a 9070.

comments.text:
@levygaming3133  ​ Because a console is GPU.
-Central die
-In the middle of a PCB
-Surrounded by GDDDR6
-VRM on either sider
-Heatsink and fan on top
-Plastic styled housing
-HDMI and 1-2 USB ports.
...annex the die with 8 small mobile cores and an NVME to boot from, bingo your GPU is now a console.
That's why they can't do anything other than game and why they cost what they do.
A 6650xt is like £230, an rx6700 was £270 and a PS5/XSX is £500.

It is the scalable nature of a PC e.g separate CPU, GPU, motherboard, expandable RAM, higher quality PSU's, metal cases.... that increases the cost.

If you're a child and ALL you do is game then a console way is a reasonable way to do that, but if you're an adult with responsibilities you're either gonna have a laptop or generic desktop anyway. Some people will try to run their life through the 6in screen of their £600+ phone using the crappy mobile versions of websites... but if you're not gonna factor that in to the price "because I have that anyway" then the same is true for a PC.

Even if I never gamed I'd still have a tower PC for the 900 reasons people have them.
When GTA6 comes out allot of people will buy another console (ps6/xse) to get 60fps, I don't even have to buy a GPU because my titanV I bought for CFD is more than enough to do that (and my missus 4 year old rtx3060ti).

comments.text:
I didn’t hear them talk about driver tricks, but I think I get what you are alluding to. A driver package first of all is signed digitally against manipulation, so you have to work around that. Once you are able to alter the installation script to support the 5060, the driver itself will perform some sanity check and as far as I have heard it will work, but in sort of a safe mode at 300 MHz. So now you need to hack away at the driver binary itself (a violation of the driver license) and depend on the assumption that the 5060 Ti is indeed the perfect template for the 5060. That whole process requires someone who is an expert at reverse engineering.
The more reliable way is to use social engineering and get one of the "previewers" to share their driver with you, hehe.
P.S.: And the graphics card of course, since that's also unavailable. 😖

comments.text:
This might be a hot take, but I don't think it really matters if there's day 1 reviews for this GPU. 

Everyone who pays attention to PC & GPU reviews already knows this card sucks. We all know it'll get bad reviews. 

And the general consumer who doesn't know any better won't be the ones buying it on day 1 anyway. How would clueless, general people even know the release date? Even if they did know the release date, GPUs sell out almost instantly from bots, scalpers & those in the know.

Reviews dropping 1 day late won't be long enough of a delay to hurt any naive consumer.

Everyone else has already been told the 5060 is going to suck for a long time now, so if they choose to buy the card anyway, reviews wouldn't make difference.

Edit: And let's not forget, these poorly reviewed GPUs ALWAYS end up being the best sellers anyway, so clearly reviews don't even matter that much to people.

comments.text:
@zodwraith5745  I respect their consumer advocacy, but disagree with the severity in which they condemn 8gb.  "Is 8gb any good" and "is 8gb any good for $420 CAD good" are 2 separate topics).  8gb cards are fine for 1080p and 1440p with literally only a handful of exceptions in the max settings regard and a literal couple that are in the all the way down to medium regard.  The 3070ti, 4060ti, and 5060ti are all well fast enough cards to deserve more vram, but the 4060 and 5060 won't be running the same kinds of settings those cards will with a playable experience (HW Legacy example above showing 58 on a 5060ti is going to mean you are well below 50 on a 5060 and possibly below 45 on a 4060.  You'll be adjusting settings to be in playable range that will free up vram in those cases anyways.  It's not like the games are magically no longer scaling down to 8gb hardware like HWUB makes it out to be.

I personally think developers should be a lot more diligent about not allowing for memory capacity bottlenecks in settings, either with stark warnings like we see in games like Forza horizon 5, RE8, and more that monitor projected vram usage and actually let the user know when they are over doing it.  showing where something CAN fail and ignoring where it excels has just turned me off of their content.

the 5060 uses Blackwell's 60-class GPU (the GB206, a slightly cut down 5060 Ti), the 4060 uses a lesser GPU (AD107) than the 4060 Ti (AD106) and if nVidia was consistent with branding their GPU codenames the 4060 should have been called, at best, a 4050 Ti, but if they had done that, it would have been harder for them to charge $300+ for it.

The 5060 should quiet clearly outperform a 4060 (I'm guessing by at least about ~10% on average for 1080p), but seems likely to lose to a 4060 Ti given that the 5060 Ti is only ~3% faster.  Being stuck on the same process-node as the 40 series has really made the 50 series look silly, but if not for the 8GB limitation, the 5060 would likely have been one of the bigger success stories of the generation.

​ @Dempig  You are trolling badly but I'll bite anyway, in what way is 9070 outdated? No MFG? MFG is useless unless you have a 240hz+ monitor, most people game on 120hz or 144hz and ordinary double frame generation is enough for that. Generating more frames than your monitor can show is useless as generating interpolated fake frames is not the same thing as performance. DLSS? FSR4 is very comparable to DLSS 4 transformer model unless you pixel peep.

RTX HDR and RTX video super resolution are the only things AMD sadly lacks but it is only a matter of time before they make something equivalent to those now that they have ML hardware in their cards.

comments.author: @MaaZeus

comments.text: @MaaZeus   poor RT performance (cant use path tracing at all) , unusable at 4k, last gen upscaling with poor game support (its nowhere near dlss4, its a dlss3 equivalent), slow ddr6 memory
comments.author: @Dempig

comments.text:
​ @Dempig RT performance is fine now, and Path Tracing is future tech that no card but 5090 can do reliably anyway. I use 9070XT in 4K, with upscaling of course, something I couldn't do with my 3070 for a long time. Upscaling support will fix itself over time, but until that time hacking it in with Optiscaler works great. And no, FSR4 is more comparable to DLSS4, I know I used it with 3070 and did not observe image quality loss worth mentioning with FSR4. And now that AMD has gone machine learning route for their upscaling, direction they can go is up. In case you didn't notice, DLSS4 transformer model wasn't some exclusive feature either, all DLSS capable cards could do it and AMD now have feature parity in that department as far as hardware goes, they can improve their upscaling just like Nvidia did.
GDDR6 slow? It is more than enough for cards of this power level. Case in point, Nvidias 5000 vs 4000 serie. The single digit performance improvements for mainstream 5000 serie cards didn't come from GDDR7, they came from Nvidia pushing more power through the cards. Faster vram does nothing unless the GPU chip itself can make use of it. Cards other than 5090 can not, GDDR7 is a waste of money for them.
comments.author: @MaaZeus

comments.text: @Dempig  RT performance is fine and path tracing is meaningless in this class of cards, 4k performance is fine with upscaling and game support will fix itself with time. Until then Optiscaler works for most not online games. And FSR4 is closer to DLSS4 than it is to 3 and now that AMD has gone Machine Learning route they can update their FSR just like Nvidia has done with DLSS. DLSS4 was not an exclusive feature as you may know. GDDR6 is enough for this class of GPU's, faster memory is a waste unless the GPU can actually use it. For comparison Nvidia 4000 series had GDDR6 and jump to GDDR7 did not provide any performance improvements. Most of the improvements for 5000 series came from Nvidia pushing more power through their cards than previously, not from faster memory. 5090 on the other hand probably calls for GDDR7.

comments.text: @aricrudd6579  NVIDIA absolutely did. I remember when they were making the gsync DIY modules for the Asus VG248QE. Then later it came out in the PG278Q. Not only that but they really thought it through. You could see with an oscilloscope how it started doubling the refresh rate when the frame rate dropped to 36fps to get around the minimum refresh rate of the monitor. It also had variable overdrive that was changing in real time without increasing latency! It's an insane technology. I remember all the discussions we had in the blur busters forums back in the day. It's one of the most transformative tech we got in modern times for gaming.

comments.text: @ A 4060 or 5060 might be a big upgrade for someone coming from a GTX 1060 or GTX 1650 but that doesn’t mean they are good products. Developers have around 12GB of memory available to them on current gen consoles and that’s including the more efficient unified memory architecture used by the consoles. PC having split video and system memory means that there needs to be more of it with 12GB being the usable minimum. The next PlayStation and Xbox consoles will be coming in 2027 or 2028 and they will have 24GB or 32GB of GDDR7 memory so 8GB graphics cards will become even more outdated. Next generation consoles will make 16GB graphics cards the minimum for most triple A games. The Xbox One and PS4 from nearly 12 years ago had 8GB of memory. It is not that great for someone coming from a GTX 1060 to only get an additional 2GB of video memory on a product that is 7-8 years newer.

comments.text: @SUTH_33  Is there a noticeable difference between DDR6 and DDR7 in gaming?
comments.author: @subject8776

comments.text:
​@subject8776 depends on the bus size. The determining factor is total bandwidth, so faster RAM but small bus (Nvidia) can be slower than slower RAM but a wider bss. So the AMD GDDR6 is a non-issue since they have a wide enough bus to end up with the same bandwidth more or less, probably for less money.

Think of it like buying a DDR5 system but only running in single channel mode
comments.author: @kalle5548

comments.text: @kalle5548  What about the 5070 Ti vs 9070 XT? They have the same bus but the former has GDDR7.
comments.author: @subject8776

comments.text:
​ @subject8776  In that case the bandwidth is lower, both have a 256 bit bus and the 5070ti has ~ 900GB/s and the 9070xt ~ 650GB/s 
As long as you have enough for the resolution and settings and fps it tends to be fine, but the 5070ti probably scales better with higher resolutions. But it's just one of several factors, and considering how well the 9070xt performs it doesn't seem to be to bottlenecked by it  :)

@mastroitek  It should be de rigour for GOTY versions or rereleases, just make the "higher HD pack" a) BETTER than the old one (for a case where that wasn't the case, look at Fallout4 HD pack) and  b) available for "free download" so users of the old version can download a copy to replay the game, whilst the GOTY or whatever version gets it bundled in. Higher textures take no GPU power (well, some, but very little) but they do take up a lot of VRAM (not ALL of it, but a large amount of it).

comments.text:
They could have done two things.
1) Underclock the card until its performance was low, but therefore also the power low, and require that for an 8GB card. Then price it for that spec. The chip is a cut down one, and if it yields well, then there may be very few that need to be cut down this far, meaning it is good silicon going to waste. But giving it 8GB is ALSO good silicon going to waste, and there there are, doing that.
2) Overclock. Massively. So that the performance goes up, but you can only get that from cutting out the cores that can't manage to clock that high. Then pricing it equal to a 16GB version for "normal users". This makes it a multiplayer Fortnite/MOBA/whatever competition level card, where textures are Low to make targets FAR more visible, and high framerates to make it possible to be more accurate and quicker to turn in a game, but also making it not require anywhere NEAR 8GB of VRAM to run because all those settings are set to Low.
Either works, option 2 makes it a competitive multiplayer only card, and the high price is because it is so niche. Option 1 saves some chips that would otherwise get thrown in the trash, and therefore even if having to bulk the numbers with silicon that could go to the 5060Ti instead, it isn't cutting THAT far into margins, but for that opportunity cost, accessing a market that aren't going to spend what the 5060Ti demands.
If yields are so good, then just go with a "nearly full fat" (so you cut SOME otherwise good silicon, but 90% of the dies you get out of a wafer are able to meet the spec), and just have one chip per "range", so no "Ti" or "Super" or "XT". That means three to five "consumer grade" designs for NVidia or two to three for AMD (when they aren't playing for top tier comparisons), then that is the cost of using good yield designs with a good foundry and a low rate of cutting off good silicon. OR ignore the "but what about cutting good silicon?!?!?", and price the card that is cut down AS IF THAT IS ALL THE CHIP CAN MANAGE, and if the maker decides to cut good silicon because they need more of those lower tier cards, JUST SUCK UP THE PRICE LOSS, DO NOT ask customers to pay for your choices.

comments.text:
@ no, it’s not about optimization (or at least not always) higher resolution textures and assets simply occupy more space, that’s the reality of the situation, and the current gen of consoles basically can allocate 12GB for games, so 8GB is not the target for those base assets, so or you play older games, not demanding new games or simply you dial down the graphic settings considerably, the only reason you can get away in some form shape of form for now is the Xbox Series S, so if a game releases on it, it should end up working on an 8GB GPU although with the worse quality assets.

There are simply an ever increasing number of games that can not fit the better quality assets in those measly 8GB of VRAM, some will give you horrible performance, some won’t allow you to run, some look like they are running okay but you’ll experience stutters/horrible 0.1% lows, and then there is the ones that run perfectly okay while allowing you to set the high resolution textures but they cheat to do so, simply because they don’t load the textures that don’t fit, an example of this is Warhammer Space Marine 2, look the videos, if you have played that game on 4K and thought it ran well, yes it did, in exchange of not loading assets properly.

And don’t get me started on Ray Tracing that increases even more the VRAM usage.

8GB of VRAM was not even ideal on the 3000 series, that’s why the 3060 age very well, while the 3070 did it poorly, NVIDIA new what they were doing

comments.text: ​@deathtrooper2048  you can't optimize 4k textures beyond the compression algorithm. Just the diffuse texture alone for something that size can reach up to 80mb alone uncompressed, plus any normal maps, ambient occlusion maps, metallic maps, all this used for a SINGLE material for one mesh. Some models can have multiple materials. Now multiply all that by the number of models in the game world, and account for the fact the gpu also needs to store each drawn frame in vram, so there's still some extra space taken up, which takes even more the higher the resolution you're running (i.e. I played Cyberpunk maxed out native 1080p and it was eating around 8gb, my dad tried 4k with DLSS Quality, same max settings and RT (before path tracing) and his vram usage hovered between 10 and 11gb, almost maxing out his 3060 (he uses it for video editing, not gaming, hence the 4k monitor)
comments.author: @OfficialDJSoru

comments.text:
Switched from a 3060 12GB to a 7800 XT recently. My 3060 worked great for me until a few months ago, suddenly my monitor would get no display output quite often (black screen) at startup and it frustrated me to no end trying to fix it. I even bought a new displayport cable and tried switching to an HDMI cable but that didn't help. Can't roll back the driver update or enter BIOS because there's no display output, I couldn't see anything. Sometimes it would randlmly start working again after 20+ power cycles. Nvidia Control Panel is ancient and almost useless, GeForce Experience kinda sucked and the new Nvidia app is somewhat decent.

Upgraded to a 7800 XT and it can keep up with my new 1440p 240hz monitor just fine. The Adrenaline software is great, I like it a little bit better than the Nvidia app and it has all the features I used when I had the 3060. Literally zero driver/software issues so far although it's only been a couple months. Like I said the first ~3 years using a 3060 was great too until a few months ago.

If anybody is on the fence about making the switch I'm here to say don't worry about FOMO on Nvidia features like RT and DLSS. Get your hands on a 9070/XT for a decent price if you can, if not, look for a used 6700 XT (12GB) or better.
